title: Python
description: A general-purpose Python quick reference covering syntax, functions, modules, common pitfalls, and day-to-day patterns.

categories.title: Installation and Tooling
categories.description: Common commands for running Python, managing environments, and packages.

items.title: Python and pip basics
items.description: Prefer python3 and pip3 on Linux/macOS (depends on your system).

rows: Run a module as a script

items.example:
python --version
python -m pip install -r requirements.txt
python app.py

items.title: Virtual environments
items.description: Use venv to isolate dependencies per project.
items.example:
python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
python -m pip install requests

categories.title: Basic Functionality
categories.description: Core syntax: variables, types, strings, formatting, and basic I/O.

items.title: Variables and types
items.description: Python is dynamically typed; type hints are optional but useful.
items.example:
name = 'Ada'
age = 36
active = True
print(name, age, active, type(age))

items.title: Strings
items.description: Use f-strings for formatting; strings are immutable.
items.example:
name = 'World'
print(f'Hello {name}')
s = ' a,b,c '
print([p.strip() for p in s.split(',')])

items.title: Input and output
items.description: Use print() for output; input() reads from stdin.
items.example:
import sys
print('hello')
print('oops', file=sys.stderr)

categories.title: Functions
categories.description: Parameters, returns, scope, anonymous functions, and common built-ins.

items.title: Parameters and returns
items.description: Supports defaults, keyword-only args, variadics (*args/**kwargs), and multiple returns via tuples.
items.example:
def divmod2(a: int, b: int) -> tuple[int, int]:
    return a // b, a % b

q, r = divmod2(10, 3)
print(q, r)

items.title: Scope (LEGB) and globals
items.description: Python resolves names with LEGB: Local, Enclosing, Global, Builtins.

rows: Bind a name in module scope
Bind a name in nearest enclosing function scope

items.example:
x = 1

def outer():
    y = 2
    def inner():
        nonlocal y
        y += 1
        return y
    return inner

inc = outer()
print(inc(), inc())

items.title: Anonymous functions
items.description: lambda is limited to a single expression; prefer def for anything non-trivial.

rows: def make_adder(n): return lambda x: x+n

items.example:
users = [{'name': 'Ada'}, {'name': 'Linus'}]
print(sorted(users, key=lambda u: u['name']))

items.title: Built-in / predefined functions (common)
items.description: A small sampling of frequently used built-ins.
items.example:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
print(sum(nums), any(n > 3 for n in nums))

items.title: Filtering and mapping
items.description: List comprehensions are the idiomatic approach.

rows: [x for x in xs if x > 0]
[x * 2 for x in xs if x > 0]

items.example:
xs = [-2, -1, 0, 1, 2]
print([x * 2 for x in xs if x > 0])

items.title: Parsing and validation
items.description: Use int()/float() for parsing and exceptions for invalid input.

categories.title: Globals
categories.description: Module-level state and common global namespaces.

items.title: Global variables
items.description: Globals are module-level names. Prefer passing dependencies explicitly.
items.example:
DEFAULT_TIMEOUT = 5

count = 0

def bump():
    global count
    count += 1

bump()
print(count)

items.title: Environment variables
items.description: Use os.environ / os.getenv for configuration.
items.example:
import os
print(os.getenv('HOME'))
print(os.getenv('APP_ENV', 'dev'))

items.title: Imports
items.description: Prefer absolute imports in packages; use aliases to avoid name collisions.
items.example:
from pathlib import Path
import json

print(Path('.').resolve())
print(json.dumps({'ok': True}))

items.title: pip and project deps
items.description: requirements.txt is common; modern projects often use pyproject.toml (pip, poetry, uv, etc.).

rows: Editable install of a local package

items.example:
python -m pip install -r requirements.txt
python -m pip freeze > requirements.txt

items.title: Comparison, boolean, membership, identity
items.description: Use is for identity (None checks), == for value equality.

rows: No ternary operator; use x if cond else y

items.example:
x = None
print(x is None)
print('a' in 'cat')
print('yes' if 1 < 2 else 'no')

items.title: Typical exceptions

rows: Value has correct type but invalid (e.g., int('x'))
Missing dependency or wrong module path

items.example:
d = {}
print(d.get('missing', 'default'))  # avoids KeyError

items.title: Common gotchas
items.description: A few frequent surprises.

rows: Use None and create inside function
Avoid naming variables list, dict, str, etc. Avoid naming files after modules like os or json.

categories.title: Arrays
categories.description: Python uses lists/tuples for sequences, and dicts/sets for collections.

items.title: Lists, tuples, sets, dicts
items.example:
xs = [1, 2, 3]
xs.append(4)
print(xs, xs[1:3])

m = {'a': 1}
print(m.get('b', 0))

items.title: Comprehensions
items.description: Comprehensions are concise and idiomatic.

rows: [x * 2 for x in xs if x > 0]
{k: v for k, v in pairs}

items.example:
xs = [1, 2, 3, 4]
print([x * 2 for x in xs if x % 2 == 0])
print({x: x*x for x in xs})

items.title: for / while
items.description: Use enumerate() for index+value; use break/continue as needed.

categories.title: Conditions
categories.description: Branching with if/elif/else and pattern matching (Python 3.10+).

items.title: if / elif / else
match / case (3.10+)
items.description: Structural pattern matching can replace some switch-style logic.
items.example:
code = 404
match code:
    case 200:
        msg = 'OK'
    case 404:
        msg = 'Not Found'
    case _:
        msg = 'Other'
print(msg)

categories.title: Regular Expressions
categories.description: The re module supports PCRE-like syntax.

items.title: re basics
items.example:
import re

pat = re.compile(r'^(\w+)@(\w+)\.(\w+)$')
m = pat.fullmatch('a@example.com')
print(m.group(1) if m else None)

categories.title: Date and Time
categories.description: Use datetime and timezone-aware values for real applications.

items.title: datetime essentials
items.example:
from datetime import datetime, timedelta, timezone

dt = datetime.now(timezone.utc)
print(dt.isoformat())
print((dt + timedelta(days=1)).isoformat())

categories.title: Database Interactions
categories.description: Python DB access varies by driver; use parameterized queries to avoid SQL injection.

items.title: SQLite (stdlib: sqlite3)
items.description: sqlite3 is built-in and is great for demos and local tools.
items.example:
import sqlite3

con = sqlite3.connect(':memory:')
cur = con.cursor()
cur.execute('CREATE TABLE users(id INTEGER, name TEXT)')
cur.execute('INSERT INTO users VALUES(?, ?)', (1, 'Ada'))
con.commit()
cur.execute('SELECT name FROM users WHERE id=?', (1,))
print(cur.fetchone())

items.title: DB-API notes
items.description: Most SQL drivers follow PEP 249 (DB-API 2.0).
